bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, February 7, 1942

div1.p: Andrus informs Truby that he is altering some details in his manuscript so that it better accords with Truby's account. Andrus identifies people in photographs, makes references to World War II, and writes about Ames and Agramonte.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, February 7, 1942
div1.opener:
J. H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
2-7-42
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Dear General:
div1.p:
Thank you for your letters of Jan. 26th and Feb. 1st. Of
course I am glad that your memoir is finished and I hope you
find a publisher very quickly, and I have little doubt but
that you will.

My only fear is that, now that it is completed, there will be
no more letters from you. I have thoroughly enjoyed our
excursions into the past as well as all other phases of our
correspondence...

As regards the Guanajay episode, I made a copy of that port-
ion of your manuscript which touched upon the same details
covered in my “Big Moment” chapter, and shall re-write mine
so they agree.

I realize, of course, that what I write is not of the least
importance as my story is not intended for publication.
Perhaps some day my son or grandchildren may compare my type-
script with your book. They will agree...

As a matter of fact, I am more than willing to agree that you
are far more likely to be right, on the minor points at var-
iance, than I. The entire incident was the most harrowing
that I have ever experienced so there may be some justifica-
tion for getting some details distorted after 40 years...

Thank you for the information about cellophane. So far I
have been unable to locate any except the thin...

See West
folder

The West picture puts me on the spot. I told you that I
was certain that No. 27 in the group photograph was Fred G.
West, the detachment barber, and not Clyde L. West. If
you find that I was in error in this you will question the
accuracy of many other assertions I have made.

In spite of the fact that you have a letter from Clyde say-
ing that he is No. 27, I stick to my guns. (There must
be some explanation of this - are you sure that he refers
to the same group photograph we refer to?)

This involves my reliability or I would not persist. If
anyone were to tell me that No. 1, in the group, was Dr.
Pinto instead of Lieut. Truby, you would not blame me for
dissenting. I knew Fred G. and Clyde L. very much better
than either of the officers referred to.
General Truby
Page 2.

If there was no way of settling this issue I would have drop-
ped it but there is a way. Under date of Dec. 18th I had
a letter from another guinea pig, James L. Hanberry, in which
he asked if I had Clyde West's address.
(I haven't. He visited me several times
when I was at Walter Reed Hospital and gave
me a Maryland address. A Christmas card
mailed there this year was returned as unde-
liverable.)

If you will send a print of the group photograph to
James L. Hanberry,
61 Summers Ave.,
Orangeburg, S. C. he should be able to
clear up the matter of identification of West and to check
all others in the group...

Had a letter from Lambert, today, saying that Dr. Hench had
visited him on his return from Washington two or three weeks
ago and planned to return at a later date. He says that
Dr. Hench also visited Forbes' mother.

Forbes has been something of a mystery - to me at least.
I don't remember the source but from somewhere I have gather-
ed the impression that the Vererans' Bureau have had no
address for Forbes and have been unable to pay him any of the
annuity to which he is entitled...

Your comments relative the Batan Peninsula arrived yesterday
with the current “Life” containing a map of the area.
Your letter and the map, in combination, give me a far better
understanding of Gen. MacArthur's situation.

One vital element does not seem to be clearly understood by
our military analysts and commentators. Some seem to
think that Gen. MacArthur is being supplied to replenish
disbursements of food and munitions. Others, that he can
not be supplied and that he and his men face inevitable
death or capture. Which is right?

I am terribly disappointed at the way the war - all of it ex-
cept on the Russian front - is going.
With best wishes and kindest regards,

Sincerely,
J H Andrus
General Truby
Page 3.

item.p:
p 79 “The Governor-General had, of course, approved the Board's
plan of testing Finlay's theory on volunteers”...

Are you sure General Wood's approval hadbbeen secured at this
time? Dean, you will remember, had been designated as XY
because authorization for his inoculation had not been obtained.

list.item:
p 92 On the sixth line you refer to the Post Commander's consent
not having been given. Was the Post Commander's consent
necessary in addition to authorization by General Wood? Yes as he
did not then know of Reed's conference with Gen Wood-

p 115 Folk (not Faulk) Writing of Folk and Jernegan you say,
“Both of these men then took the mosquito test and both developed
yellow fever. Jernegan's mosquito inoculation was nega-
tive. He was finally given yellow fever by blood inocula-
tion. You cover this beautifully on p 113.

p 116 No. 14 in the group photograph is not Jernegan but Private
Kneisley. Jernegan's likeness in the painting, “Conquerors
of Yellow Fever” was copied from a print I furnished Mr. Kel-
log. I knew both men and am certain.
p 177 No. 40 is not Weatherwalks but Private John Colby.

p 118 Add to “Volunteers Not Shown” Warren G. Jernegan and Edward
Weatherwalks.

item.p:
p 118 - foot “During the entire period of the Board's work, he
(Agramonte) was in charge of the large department laboratory,
located at Military Hospital No. 1, on Principe Hill.”
The Lab.
was contained-

Military Hospital No. 1 was closed April 29, 1900. I have
record of this in a sketchy diary kept during my military ser-
vice. I recall that all patients had been removed and the
large detachment of Corps Men assigned to different posts.
Finally, on April 29, there were not more than 10 or 12 of us
left. All of us departed on that date, Schwieger and I
going to Guanajay and the others to other posts.

On page 53 you speak of Dr. Ames reporting to Columbia Barracks
on April 10, 1900, coming from Military Hospital No. 1.
His reassignment was probably due to closing No. 1.

I have no doubt about Dr. Agramonte having a laboratory in
Havana that occupied most of his time. He MUST have had
duties elsewhere or he would have died of boredom for he was
rarely at Major Reed's laboratory and there was little he
COULD have done at Camp Lazear. I was not at the latter
point and do not know whether he ever did anything there
or not.

list.item:
p 152 Am not sure about experimental cases being taken to the yel-
low fever hospital on their beds. I was not. I was,
however, taken on a litter.

div1.p: With kindest regards and every good wish,
